description: From Middle English standen, stonden (verb) and stand, stond (noun, from the verb), from Old English standan (“to stand, occupy a place”), from Proto-West Germanic *standan, from Proto-Germanic *standaną (“to stand”), from Pre-Germanic *sth₂-n-t-´, an innovative extended n-infixed form of Proto-Indo-European *steh₂-.

entries.meaning: The act of standing.
examples: I took my stand upon an eminence […] to look into their several ladings.

entries.meaning: A defensive position or effort.
examples: The Commander says we will make our stand here.

entries.meaning: A resolute, unwavering position; firm opinion; action for a purpose in the face of opposition.
examples: They took a firm stand against copyright infringement.

entries.meaning: A period of performance in a given location or venue.
examples: They have a four-game stand at home against the Yankees.  They spent the summer touring giving 4 one-night stands a week.

entries.meaning: A device to hold something upright or aloft.
examples: He set the music upon the stand and began to play.  an umbrella stand;  a hat-stand

entries.meaning: The platform on which a witness testifies in court; the witness stand or witness box.
examples: She took the stand and quietly answered questions.

entries.meaning: (historical) An area of raised seating for waiters at the stock exchange.
examples: When a member has failed to comply with his bargains the fact is announced from one of the stands,  […]

entries.meaning: A particular grove or other group of trees or shrubs.
examples: This stand of pines is older than the one next to it.

entries.meaning: (forestry) A contiguous group of trees sufficiently uniform in age-class distribution, composition, and structure, and growing on a site of sufficiently uniform quality, to be a distinguishable unit.
A standstill, a motionless state, as of someone confused, or a hunting dog who has found game.
examples: One of the later school of the Grecians, examineth the matter, and is at a stand, to think what should be in it, that men should love lies; where neither they make for pleasure, as with poets, nor for advantage, as with the merchant; but for the lie’s sake.

entries.meaning: A small building, booth, or stage, as in a bandstand or hamburger stand.
A designated spot where someone or something may stand or wait.
examples: a taxi stand

entries.meaning: (US, dated) The situation of a shop, store, hotel, etc.
examples: a good, bad, or convenient stand for business

entries.meaning: (US, historical) Short for tavern stand (“a roadside inn”).
(sports) Grandstand. (often in the plural)
(cricket) A partnership.
(military, plural often stand) A single set, as of arms.
(obsolete) Rank; post; station; standing.
(dated) A state of perplexity or embarrassment.
examples: to be at a stand what to do

entries.meaning: A young tree, usually reserved when other trees are cut; also, a tree growing or standing upon its own root, in distinction from one produced from a scion set in a stock, either of the same or another kind of tree.
A location or position where one may stand.
(advertising) An advertisement filling an entire billboard, comprising many sheets of paper.
examples: The cost of the printing alone will average $2 a 'stand.' The sheets are about 28x42 inches and are in four colors, which means they must go through the process four times.

entries.meaning: (fiction) A type of supernatural ability from the anime and manga series JoJo's Bizarre Adventure, named for the fact that they appear to 'stand' next to their user.

verbs.description: stand (third-person singular simple present stands, present participle standing, simple past stood, past participle stood or (obsolete) standen or (nonstandard) stand)

definitionGroups.group: To position or be positioned physically:

entries.meaning: (intransitive, copulative) To support oneself on the feet in an erect position.
examples: Here I stand, wondering what to do next.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To rise to one’s feet; to stand up.
examples: Stand up, walk to the refrigerator, and get your own snack.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, copulative) To remain motionless.
examples: Do not leave your car standing in the road.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be placed in an upright or vertical orientation.
examples: He seized the gun which always stood in a corner of his bedroom […].

entries.meaning: (transitive) To place in an upright or standing position.
examples: He stood the broom in a corner and took a break.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To occupy or hold a place; to be set, placed, fixed, located, or situated.
examples: Paris stands on the Seine.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To measure when erect on the feet.
examples: His face, as I grant, in spite of spite, / Has a broad-blown comeliness, red and white, / And six feet two, as I think, he stands;

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of tears, sweat, etc.) To be present, to have welled up.
examples: now my heart beginneth to melt within me being wounded (with that the tears stood in his eyes) to see the faces of some here present, whom J most earnestly love, and now must depart from with shame  […]

definitionGroups.group: To position or be positioned mentally:

entries.meaning: (intransitive, followed by to + infinitive) To be positioned to gain or lose.
examples: He stands to get a good price for the house.

entries.meaning: (transitive, negative) To tolerate.
examples: I can’t stand when people don’t read the instructions.
I can’t stand him.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, copulative) To maintain one's ground; to be acquitted; not to fail or yield; to be safe.
examples: readers by whose judgment I would stand or fall

entries.meaning: (intransitive, copulative) To maintain an invincible or permanent attitude; to be fixed, steady, or firm; to take a position in resistance or opposition.
examples: The king granted the Jews […] to gather themselves together, and to stand for their life.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, copulative, obsolete) To be in some particular state; to have essence or being; to be; to consist.
examples: sacrifices […] which stood only in meats and drinks

definitionGroups.group: To position or be positioned socially:

entries.meaning: (intransitive, cricket) To act as an umpire.
(transitive) To undergo; withstand; hold up.
examples: The works of Shakespeare have stood the test of time.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, Britain) To be a candidate (in an election).
examples: He is standing for election to the local council.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be valid.
examples: What I said yesterday still stands.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To oppose, usually as a team, in competition.
examples: "Kim, Jack, and I will stand you guys," Jimmie Burdette said. ¶ "We'll smear you!" laughed Ron.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cover the expense of; to pay for.
examples: to stand a round of drinks
to stand a treat
to stand bail (security in respect of an arrested person)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have or maintain a position, order, or rank; to be in a particular relation.
examples: Christian charity, or love, stands first in the rank of gifts.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be consistent; to agree; to accord.
examples: Doubt me not; by heaven, I will do nothing / But what may stand with honour.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To appear in court.
(intransitive, nautical) Of a ship or its captain, to steer, sail (in a specified direction, for a specified destination etc.).
examples: To repaire his defects, hee stood for the coast of Calabria, but hearing there was six or seven Galleyes at Mesina hee departed thence for Malta […].

entries.meaning: (intransitive, copulative) To remain without ruin or injury.
examples: My mind on its own centre stands unmov'd.

entries.meaning: (card games) To stop asking for more cards; to keep one's hand as it has been dealt so far.

description: From Middle English stand, stande, stond, stonde, stoonde, probably from Middle Dutch stande, from Old Dutch *standan (“to stand”), from Frankish *standan.
Forms with -o- may show influence of stonden (“stand”, verb).

entries.meaning: (US, Scotland, dated) A container which stands upright, such as a barrel or cask.
(obsolete) A weight of from two hundred and fifty to three hundred pounds, used in weighing pitch.
